--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
<snip>
> Well actually the most widely-accepted definition of
> evolution is simply a change in the frequency of
> genes
> in a population.  Evolution is not inherently
> directional; it is simply change.
> 
> And change could easily be demonstrated in NEAT
> without a fitness function.  Given a population of
> 100
> individuals, 20% could simply be randomly selected
> to
> produce offspring via the NEAT mating method, which
> would then be subject to NEAT's mutation operators,
> refilling the population to its original size.  20%
> could then be randomly selected to survive into the
> next generation...and so on.
> 
> Even with no fitness function, the population will
> evolve.  That is, the gene frequencies of the final
> generation will be different from the original
> population (just how different will depend on
> parameter settings, such as mutation rates).
> 
> And that's all evolution is.  No intent.  No
> direction.
> 
> Of course, for our purposes, we want the change to
> go
> in a particular direction, to optimize a particular
> behavior or set of behaviors, and we try to tailor a
> fitness function that we think best captures the
> features of those behaviors.  We're interested in
> directional change.
> 
> But strictly speaking, biological evolution is not.

Let me be the first to disagree with you.  I expect
many others will also disagree.  Of course words are
given definitions by people, so there is never
complete agreement.  Nevertheless, evolution as a
scientific theory includes the idea of selection.  The
selection is based on the total environment, and
causes a directional movement of gene frequencies. 
The direction may or may not be predictable.  Granted,
there are cases where there is only random selection,
and hence genetic drift is the only source of gene
frequency change, but in most case, both biological
and simulated, the selection that occurs will push the
gene pool in specific directions.
